abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the project were as
            follows: the outcome was satisfactory, the sustainability
            was likely, the institutional development impact was
            substantial, the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the
            borrower performance was unsatisfactory. The lessons learned
            indicate that Social Protection Implementation Loan (SPIL)
            had a sufficient degree of flexibility to provide adequate
            reform-oriented technical assistance to the government in an
            uncertain environment. SPIL had many small-scale Technical
            Assistance (TA) contracts which made project management more
            complicated. The regional governments in which SPIL pilot
            projects were implemented were actively involved in
            preparation of assignments which contributed to the success
            of project activities, most notably on child allowances
            program. Although the project involved numerous activities
            to disseminate materials through seminars and publications,
            more could have been be done to provide access to the
            experience obtained, for example, putting materials on
            internet. SPIL itself would have benefited from a PR
            campaign to explain to a wide audience, especially the State
            Duma and other state agencies, the purpose and objectives of
            the project. Given the high volume of procurement for the
            project, the contract with the external procurement firm was
            of great assistance. Outsourcing of some procurement work in
            such a complex project helps assure that procurement moves smoothly.
